A series of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts for low-temperature catalytic combustion of methane were successfully prepared by synthetic induction of CuMn2O4 precursors via hydrothermal method which used deep eutectic solvent (DES) as an inducer. The structure and properties of the catalyst were investigated by XRD, BET, XPS and SEM characterizations to investigate the effect of DES addition on the crystal growth of the catalyst. The results showed that the Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalyst produced a new phase of MnCO3, which changed the number and distribution of acid-base sites on the catalyst surface and effectively promoted the desorption of catalytic reaction products. The catalytic activity test showed that the methane catalytic activity of the Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalyst was significantly enhanced at Mn/C molar ratio of 1:2.5, with T50 and T90 values of 365 °C and 425 °C, respectively. This can be attributed to the high proportional distribution of high-valent manganese in the internal electronic structure of the composite catalyst system, which generated a large number of surface adsorbed oxygen species and thus facilitated the oxidation of methane at lower temperatures. Thermal analysis of composite catalysts revealed relatively high activation energy and thermal stability in the combustion process of composite catalysts. This study will lead to innovative insights into the design of composite catalysts for methane oxidation. Graphical abstract A series of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts for methane catalytic combustion were fabricated and considered the effects of deep eutectic solvent (DES) as an organic carbon source, different amounts (1:1, 1:2, 1:2.5, 1:3.5, 1:5) of DES were selected for experiment. The composites exhibited different degrees of altered catalytic activity and elements of the composition. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methane Catalytic oxidation CuMn2O4 Hydrothermal induction 1 Introduction Today, energy demand has become one of the world's major problems, and although great progress has been made in renewable energy sources, fossil energy sources (oil, coal, natural gas) still dominate [1]. Meanwhile, the prevalence of low concentration methane in coalbed methane and waste gas is of great concern. They are difficult to utilize effectively because of its high emissions, low concentration, and low calorific value [2–3]. The direct emission of methane at low concentrations not only generates wasteful resources and polluting emissions, but also has serious environmental, health and safety impacts [4–5]. Because methane molecules are relatively stable and not easily activated, the combustion temperature can be as high as 1100 °C when treated by the traditional methane combustion method, which leads to energy waste [6–9]. Catalytic combustion of methane is an effective way to reduce methane emissions at low concentrations and reveals high durability [10–11]. This process should include at least four dehydrogenation steps and two basic steps of CO coupling [12–13]. Catalytic combustion not only improves the low-temperature conversion rate of low-concentration methane, but also avoids the generation and emission of polluting gasses [14–17]. Hence, it is meaningful to design high efficiency catalyst to achieve the higher conversion at low temperature. Studies have shown that metal oxide catalysts are of interest for catalytic oxidation applications because of their higher thermal stability and lower cost, although they do not have significantly better catalytic performance than precious metal catalysts [18–21]. It is found that the synergistic effect between different components and ionic valence states of composite catalyst materials can effectively improve the catalyst structure and induce the exposure of more active sites on its surface, which can overcome the defects of poor stability and high-temperature aging structure in single-component oxides [22–24], and optimize the acid-base properties of the surface components [25] to improve the redox properties and catalytic performance of the composite catalysts. [26–27]. Niu et al. [28] demonstrated that the excellent catalytic performance of CuMn2O4 spinel was attributed to the synergistic effect of redox properties and Lewis's acid sites in the catalyst. The Lewis acid site accelerated the adsorption and activation of molecular oxygen to form surface oxygen species, and the redox properties promoted the deep catalytic oxidation of intermediates or by-products to CO2 and H2O. Zhang et al. [29] synthesized a series of nanocrystalline copper-manganese spinel oxides by sol-gel method. The copper-manganese spinel compounds prepared by this method provided abundant porous structures and metal valence states, which greatly improved the catalytic activity. The main role of deep eutectic solvents (DES) as solvents for different kinds of solutes (such as organic substances and metal oxides) was to dissolve solute particles (molecules or ions) and also to prepare well-defined and shape-controlled nanomaterials. X. Ge et al. [30] used an inexpensive deep eutectic solvent (DES) system to synthesize LDH precursors, and the Co-Fe oxide calcined Co2.698Fe0.302O4 with small grain size, nanosheet morphology and porous structure exhibited excellent adsorption capacity for organic waste and toxic heavy metal ions. The related studies have also shown that DES with moderate to high viscosity help to improve nanoparticle dispersion [31]. Herein, in this study, we focused on the synthetic induction of CuMn2O4 precursors by hydrothermal method using DES as an inducer in view of the structural characteristics and optimized properties of spinel. We successfully prepared a series of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts to investigate the mechanism of methane catalytic oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 2.1.1 Synthesis of CuMn2O4 catalyst The preparation of CuMn2O4 catalyst was by co-precipitation. The samples were prepared as follows: the metal precursors Cu(NO3)2–3H2O (2.4404 g) and Mn(NO3)2 (7.1580 g) (substance ratio Cu: Mn=1:2) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water, and the precursor solutions were stirred at room temperature for 2 h; After the precursor solution was uniformly mixed, NaOH solution with a concentration of 2 mol•L − 1 was added dropwise to adjust the pH=10 of the precursor solution during stirring; Then the precursor solution was stirred again at room temperature for 24 h. The suspension formed after stirring was filtered and washed several times with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol. The filtered samples were placed in an oven at 60 °C for 8 h. After grinding, the samples were calcined in a muffle furnace under air atmosphere at 550 °C for 3 h, in which the temperature increase rate was 3 °C•min−1. The final CuMn2O4 sample (denoted as CM) was obtained. 2.1.2 Preparation of deep eutectic solvents (DES) The detailed preparation process of DES was as follows: l-arginine (3.4840 g) and glycerol (11.0508 g) were put into a 100 ml three-necked flask in turn and stirred at 80 °C. After the precursor dissolved into transparent solution, the temperature was set to 90 °C, carbamide (4.0000 g) was added and continued to be stirred until the liquid was transparent, and DES sample was prepared. 2.1.3 Preparation of CM-xDES catalysts The CM-xDES samples were prepared by hydrothermal method. The detailed preparation process of CM-2.5DES was as follows: the as-prepared CuMn2O4 (2 g) and DES (1.5 g) were mixed with 3.2 mL of deionized water in a 50 mL polyethylene lined reactor; hydrothermal treatment was carried out at hydrothermal temperature of 180 °C and hydrothermal time of 4 h. The prepared samples were labeled as CM-2.5DES. The Mn/C molar ratios were adjusted to 1:1, 1:2, 1:3.5, and 1:5. The obtained samples were denoted as CM-1DES, CM-2DES, CM-3.5DES and CM-5DES. The preparation method of other composite catalysts (CM-1DES, CM-2DES, CM-3.5DES and CM-5DES) was the same as above, the dosages of DES were 0.6 g, 1.2 g, 2.1 g and 3 g, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Catalysts were characterized by Inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), FT-IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), CO2 Temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), NH3 Temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) (See details in the Electronic Supporting Information, ESI). 2.3 Catalytic performance measurements Details of catalytic methane tests were included in the Electronic Supporting Information (ESI). 2.4 Catalyst thermal analysis Details of the catalytic thermal analysis tests were included in the Electronic Supporting Information (ESI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Methane catalytic activity of composite catalysts Fig. 1 showed the methane catalyst activity of CM-xDES (x = 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) and MnCO3 catalysts and lifetime stability of CM-2.5DES sample. Table 1 showed the specific surface area, pore volume, pore size, T50 and T90 data of CM-xDES (x = 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) and MnCO3 catalysts (purchased from Tianjin Yongda Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.). The graphical results showed that T50 and T90 values for the Mn/C = 1:2.5 catalysts were higher than other catalysts at 365 °C and 425 °C, respectively. When the Mn/C molar ratio was less than 1:2.5, the methane catalytic activity of the modified catalyst was significantly enhanced with the increase of DES addition. When the Mn/C molar ratio was greater than 1:2.5, the methane catalytic activity of the modified catalyst was significantly decreased with the increase of DES addition. The order of activity for full conversion of methane catalyzed by different molar ratios of Mn/C catalysts was: CM-2.5DES > MnCO3 > CM-3.5DES > CM-5DES > CM-2DES > CM-1DES > CM. Meanwhile, the stability test revealed that the CM-2.5 sample still had a removal rate higher than 90% after 100 h of continuous methane-catalyzed reaction at 450 °C ( Fig. 1 -b). It could be seen that the catalyst had high thermal stability. 3.2 Actual element contents of composite catalysts The prepared samples of series of catalysts CM-xDES (x = 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) were dissolved and diluted with dilute hydrochloric acid to configure the solution. The solution was subjected to inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy test experiments to obtain the mass ratios of Cu and Mn elements, and the relative substance ratios of Cu and Mn elements could be obtained by calculation, the data were shown in Table 2 . With the change of C/Mn molar ratio, the change of the relative mole ratio of Cu and Mn elements in the catalysts was shown in Fig. 2 . It could be found that with the increase of DES addition, the Mn/Cu ratio also showed an overall increasing trend, which meant the content of the active component MnCO3 gradually increased. The Mn/Cu ratio of the modified catalysts increased, which may be caused by the loss of Cu ions during the recrystallization of CuMn2O4 by decomposition in the hydrothermal process. 3.3 Microstructure of composite catalysts The XRD patterns of the CM-xDES (x= 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) and MnCO3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . From the figure, it could be seen that the CM catalyst had a pure CuMn2O4 crystal structure and its XRD diffraction pattern was consistent with the characteristic peak of JCPDS PDF#01–074–2422 (CuMn2O4). There were two different crystal structures of the catalysts which were modified by the addition of DES. One of the diffraction spectra of the main phase was consistent with JCPDS PDF#01–073–4352 (MnCO3), which belonged to the rhombohedral hexahedral crystal system. The remaining diffraction peaks corresponded to the Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 crystalline phase, and their diffraction patterns were consistent with the characteristic peaks of JCPDS PDF#01–070–0262, which belonged to the cubic crystal system. The main peak of the diffraction pattern of the CuMn2O4 phase of the corresponding CM catalyst was shifted, indicating that the hydrothermal process led to the changes in the crystal lattice and the crystal plane. With the increase of DES addition, the diffraction peak intensity of the MnCO3 crystalline phase first increased and then decreased, while the Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 crystalline phase showed a trend of gradual decreased. It was shown that the surface metal Cu and Mn ions which dissolved from CM catalyst during the hydrothermal process. Cu and Mn in different proportions for secondary crystallization to form Cu1.5Mn1.5O4, while the excess Mn ions crystallize with carbonate ions in the hydrothermal environment to form MnCO3. The increased activity of CM-2.5DES catalyst compared to CM catalysts could be attributed to the creation of new structures. It was also found from the figure that the diffraction pattern of the MnCO3 phase in the MnCO3 catalyst was consistent with the diffraction pattern of the MnCO3 phase in the CM-2.5DES catalyst. Therefore, the CM-2.5DES catalyst had similar methane catalytic properties to the MnCO3 catalyst. As shown in Table 3 that changing the Mn/C molar ratio did not significantly change the crystal axis length, crystal axis angle and cell volume of the catalyst, which indicated that with the change of DES addition, the catalyst generated no change in the crystalline phase, but it affected the crystal growth of MnCO3. And when Mn/C = 1:2.5, it was more favorable for MnCO3 crystal growth and methane catalysis. The N2 sorption and desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of CM-xDES (x = 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) and MnCO3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 . According to the IUPAC classification, the N2 sorption and desorption isotherms of the CM-xDES (x= 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) and MnCO3 catalysts which shown in Fig. 4 -a were type IV with both H3-type hysteresis lines and the presence of no restricted adsorption in the high P/P0 state. Fig. 4 -b showed the pore size distribution of catalysts, it could be clearly found that the pore size of catalysts was mainly distributed in narrow range of 3∼x223C5 nm, which was mesoporous structure. Combined with Table 1 , we could find that the specific surface area (13.176∼x223C22.133 m2•g − 1) and pore volume (0.066∼x223C0.248 cc•g − 1) of CM-xDES (x = 0, 1, 2, 2.5, 3.5, 5) catalysts showed a clear tendency to decrease with the increase of DES addition. The specific surface area and pore size of CM-2.5DES catalysts were significantly reduced compared to CM catalysts, but the pore size increased to 3.831 nm, resulting in better methane catalytic activity. The main phase of CM-2.5DES catalyst and MnCO3 catalyst were both MnCO3 phase, and the difference in methane catalytic activity between them was not significant, but the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size were all different. These characterizations all indicated that the specific surface area, pore volume and pore size had little effect on the catalyst methane catalytic performance for CM-2.5DES catalyst and MnCO3 catalyst which both with the same active phase MnCO3. But the generation of new crystal structures was the dominant factor in improving the methane catalytic performance of CM-2.5DES catalysts. Fig. 5 showed the FT-IR spectra of CM, CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 catalysts in the wavelength range of 500∼x223C4000 cm−1. The spectrogram revealed that the CM-2.5DES catalyst absorption peaks which in the low frequency mode in the range of 800–400 cm−1 were similar to the CM catalyst. It was mainly attributed to the lattice vibrations of Mn-O, and the two strong peaks at 610 cm−1 and 504 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of Cu-O and Mn-O, respectively [32]. Moreover, the same absorption bands were observed as for the MnCO3 catalyst in the high frequency mode. Among them, two sharp and strong vibrational bands appeared at 724 cm−1 and 857 cm−1, and this could be attributed to the out-of-plane bending and in-plane bending modes of CO3 2−, respectively [33]. And the broad and strong vibration band observed at 1403 cm−1 was mainly attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of CO3 2−. The small peak located at 1802 cm−1 was mainly associated with the CO group in MnCO3 catalyst. In addition, the OH stretching vibration of the water molecule led to a broad absorption peak at 3385 cm−1 [34]. Thus, FT-IR spectra proved that the CM-2.5DES catalyst contained Cu-O, Mn-O and CO3 2− structures. This result was consistent with the results of XRD study, indicating that DES successfully induced the synthesis of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalyst. The combination of XRD, BET and FT-IR analysis data showed that the amount of DES addition affected the crystal growth of the catalysts. When Mn/C = 1:2.5, it was more favorable for crystal growth. The prepared CM-2.5DES catalyst had the best methane catalytic activity, which was significantly better than CM catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method, with T50 and T90 values of 365 °C and 425 °C, respectively. Meanwhile, FT-IR spectra demonstrated that the DES-modified composite catalyst contained Cu-O, Mn-O and CO3 2− structures, which was consistent with the results that the main phase of the composite catalyst was MnCO3 phase and contained a small amount of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 phase. This indicated that DES successfully induced the synthesis of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts. Therefore, we used CM-2.5DES catalyst as the main research target in our subsequent study to investigate the mechanism of the main phase MnCO3-catalyzed methane in the DES-induced synthesis of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts. And compared it with MnCO3 catalysts which had a single MnCO3 crystalline phase in terms of methane catalytic combustion performance and stability. 3.4 Microscopic morphology of the composite catalysts Fig. 6 showed the SEM images of CM-2.5DES catalyst at 1 μm and 500 nm, respectively. It could be found from the figure that the CM-2.5DES catalyst nanoparticles exhibited an indeterminate and uniform distribution. Among the catalyst nanoparticles, the particle size ranged from 50 to 100 nm, and the nanoparticles of different sizes were clustered together to form a rich pore structure, which was consistent with the BET characterization results. The TEM plots of CM-2.5DES catalyst at different scales were shown in Fig. 7 (a-d). Fig. 7 -a and Fig. 7 -b showed the TEM images at 500 nm and 50 nm, respectively. From the figure, we could find that the composite catalyst was uniformly distributed with indeterminate nanoparticles along with the presence of pore structures in different sizes which was consistent with the SEM and BET results. The lattice stripes of Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 and MnCO3 were shown in Fig. 7 (c-d), where Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 had a lattice spacing d = 0.454 nm and main exposed crystal plane was the (111) crystal plane. While MnCO3 exposed the (110) crystal plane with a lattice spacing d = 0.238 nm, which was consistent with the XRD characterization results. Mapping element map of CM-2.5DES catalyst was shown in Fig. 7 (e-i), from which it could be seen that Cu, Mn, C and O elements in the catalyst were uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface and without agglomeration. And this could further prove that DES had a certain viscosity which helped to enhance the dispersion of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the crystal regrowth and the generation of new active phases during hydrothermal process were beneficial to improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts for methane catalysis. The above characterization results demonstrated that the crystal structure, specific surface area, pore structure and micromorphology all affected the methane catalytic performance of the catalysts. 3.5 Crystal growth mechanism of composite catalysts The formation mechanism of Cu-Mn-C-O complex nanoparticles was shown in Fig. 8 . First, CM was added to the autoclave as the induced precursor, DES as the inducer, and water as the solvent, and then carried out the hydrothermal treatment. The hydrothermal process destroyed the CM crystal structure and formed a mixed Cu2+ and Mn3+ metal solution in the reactor. The addition of DES provided an alkaline environment for the metal solution. It was mainly attributed to the amino group of urea in DES ensured that the pH in the system (11.89) was higher than the isoelectric point of l-arginine (10.76). Where l-arginine was basic amino acid; the alkaline environment (OH−) provided by DES provided precipitant for Cu2+ and Mn3+, with Cu2+ precipitating to produce Cu (OH)2 and Mn3+ precipitating to produce Mn (OH)3. And Cu (OH)2 reacted with propanetriol in carbon-point solution to form a copper glycerol solution, while Mn (OH)3 was unstable and underwent decomposition reaction to form MnO2 and Mn (OH)2. The hydrothermal destruction of catalyst crystal structure formed Mn4+ and Mn2+. During hydrothermal process, the synthesis of urea was promoted by hydrolysis of l-arginine, and urea underwent hydrolysis reaction to produce CO3 2− and ammonia, and Mn2+ x002B and CO3 2- to produce MnCO3. Where the hydrothermally remaining Cu and Mn ions were regenerated into Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 oxides by certain stoichiometric ratio. In the hydrothermal stage, the decomposition of uninvolved N2 and NH3 by propanetriol and ammonium ions with certain viscosity at high temperature both contributed to the dispersibility of nanoparticles. And the loss of glycerol copper solution during the subsequent extraction and washing process, which led to the loss of Cu. And it was consistent with the ICP results. 3.6 Composite catalysts surface acidity and alkalinity It was shown that the acid/base active center also affected the methane catalytic performance of the catalyst [35]. The CO2 and NH3 programmed ramp-up desorption curves of CM, CM-2.5DES, and MnCO3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 9 . The surface weak to moderate strong acid base amounts were shown in Table 4 . It was known from the literature that the CO2 desorption peaks in the temperature range of 50–300 °C were attributed to physisorption or adsorption of hydroxyl groups on weakly basic sites. The desorption peaks in the temperature range of 300–600 °C represented moderately basic sites, and these were mainly attributed to decomposition of bidentate carbonate species. The desorption peaks in the temperature range of greater than 600 °C were mainly attributed to the decomposition of monodentate carbonate species which adsorbed on strong bases. Based on the results of the CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD characterization data, it was found that the CM catalyst apparently had strong acid and base densities at 806 °C and 827 °C, respectively (desorption values of 0.868 mmol•g − 1 and 147.273 mmol•g − 1, respectively). However, the CM-2.5DES catalyst modified by the addition of DES and MnCO3 catalyst showed desorption peaks at moderate acid and base sites with acid and base densities of 6.301 mmol•g − 1, 4.763 mmol•g − 1 and 8.611 mmol•g − 1, 12.184 mmol•g − 1, respectively. Compared with CM catalyst, CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 catalysts had relatively strong medium acid/base site density, which reduced the amount of CO2 desorption at strong base sites and effectively improved the desorption of catalytic reaction products. Therefore, CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 catalysts exhibited relatively excellent methane catalytic activity. 3.7 Composite catalysts surface elements composition Fig. 10 showed the X-ray photoelectron spectra of Mn2p, C1s and O1s for CM, CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 catalysts. The Mn2p spectra of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 10 -a. All samples consisted of two orbital dominant peaks, Mn2p3/2 and Mn2p1/2. The Mn2p3/2XPS spectra of CM-2.5DES and CM catalysts decomposed into three main peaks with binding energies (BE) at 640.47, 641.79, 643.56 eV and 650.59, 641.7, 642.91 eV, corresponding to the catalyst surface Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively. The Mn2p1/2 orbitals had only one main peak corresponding to Mn3+ species after the split peak fitting. The MnCO3 catalyst Mn2pXPS spectra with rotation orbital binding energies of 641.92 eV and 653.94 eV, corresponding to Mn2p3/2 and Mn2p1/2 orbitals, respectively, with splitting energy of 12 eV. It could be demonstrated that the Mn element was distributed in the +2-valence state [36]. The (Mn4++Mn3+)/Mn2+ mole ratio was shown in Table 5 . The (Mn4++Mn3+)/Mn2+ (3.9796) in the CM-2.5DES catalyst was significantly higher than CM catalyst (2.9596), indicating that more high-valence Mn was exposed on the surface of CM-2.5DES catalyst, forming higher concentration of oxygen vacancies [37]. Thus, promoting adsorption of oxygen was beneficial to improve catalytic methane activity [38]. The C1sXPS spectra of CM-2.5DES catalyst were mainly divided into two components with binding energies of 284.82 eV and 289.12 eV, corresponding to CC and CO3 2- bonds, respectively. And two peaks of the same component were also observed in CM and MnCO3 catalysts ( Fig. 10 -b) [39]. According to the data in Table 5 , comparing the CO3 2−/CC values of the three catalysts, the order from high to low was: MnCO3>CM-2.5DES>CM. It was obvious that the CO3 2- peak area of CM-2.5DES catalyst modified by DES was higher than CM catalyst, indicating that the CO3 2− content in the modified catalyst increased. Meanwhile, the CO3 2− peaks of CM-2.5DES catalyst was shifted toward higher binding energy and lower binding energy compared with CM and MnCO3 catalysts, respectively. And it indicated that there was some interaction between MnCO3 and Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 in CM-2.5DES catalyst, which was consistent with the XRD results. As shown in Fig. 10 -c, the O1sXPS spectrum of the MnCO3 catalyst had only one component corresponding to CO3 2−, while the O1sXPS spectra of CM-2.5DES and CM catalysts had two main peaks at binding energies of 531.2, 530.17 eV and 531.39, 529.89 eV, corresponding to CO3 2− and M-O bonds, respectively [40], which was consistent with the XRD results. And the lower binding energy of the catalyst corresponded to M-O as lattice oxygen species (Olat). The higher binding energy corresponded to CO3 2− and associated with the adsorbed oxygen species in oxygen vacancies (Oads) [41]. The CO3 2−/M-O ratio of the CM-2.5DES catalyst was 14.5 times higher than CM catalyst, indicating that the addition of DES increased the content of adsorbed oxygen species, which meant increasing the oxygen vacancy concentration of the catalyst. The above results indicated that the DES-induced synthesis of CM-2.5DES catalyst introduced a large amount of adsorbed oxygen species, while exposing the catalyst surface to high concentration of high-valent Manganese which indicated higher concentration of oxygen vacancies. And it could be evidenced by the (Mn4+ Mn3+)/Mn2+ ratio ( Table 6 ). Meantime, the higher concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen facilitated the oxidation of methane at lower temperatures. 3.8 Composite catalysts reduction capacity The redox ability of CM and CM-2.5DES catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR experiments and explained the mechanism of the Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts activity. As shown in Fig. 11 -a, it was observed that the H2-TPR profiles of CM catalyst was similar to the CM-2.5DES catalyst, with basically two reduction peaks. It was known from the literature that although it was not possible to attribute individual peaks to specific redox substances, the two-step reduction of spinel could be summarized as the reduction of two cationic components of spinel to CuO and Mn2+ substances [42]. Therefore, based on the comparison of reduction temperatures required for the reduction of CuO and Mn2O3, the low temperature peak of the CM catalyst can correspond to the reduction of Cu and the high temperature peak to the reduction of Mn [43]. The reduction of the CM-2.5DES catalyst was divided into two stages as follows: (1) the reduction process from Mn4+ to Mn3+ and the low temperature peak (LTP) at this stage was 346 °C; (2) Reduction process from Mn3+ to Mn2+ and the high temperature peak (HTP) at this stage was 423 °C. Table 6 showed the data of hydrogen consumption in the reduction phase for CM and CM-2.5DES catalysts. The hydrogen consumption at HTP for CM-2.5DES catalyst was 0.0588 mmol•g − 1 which was 32 times higher than CM catalyst in the high temperature phase, indicating that CM-2.5DES catalyst had more Mn3+. The above results indicated that CM-2.5DES catalyst had high concentration of high-valent manganese, the CM-2.5DES catalyst had excellent redox ability. Fig. 11 -b showed the O2-TPD of as-synthesized catalysts measured at the temperature region from 100 to 900 °C, and the results were listed in Table 6 . There are three desorption peaks (denoted as α, β, γ, respectively) in the profile of O2-TPD. The appearance of the α peak was attributed to the surface electrophilic oxygen species (superficial oxygen species (O2 −, O2 2− or O−)) desorbed at low temperature (RT-400 °C). The activated oxygen species over the available oxygen vacancies on the surface were desorbed in the temperature range of 400–700 °C, and the peaks appearing in this range were collectively considered as β peak [44–45]. Combined with the Fig. 10 -b and Table 6 , it could be seen that the temperature of the methane-catalyzed reaction was consistent with the β-peak. At 425 °C, the CM-2.5DES catalyst which modified with carbon material showed higher concentration of adsorbed oxygen (4.2418 mmol/g) at lower temperature. For the CM catalyst, the lower adsorbed oxygen concentration (1.0179 mmol/g) was achieved at 567 °C, which indicated that the composite catalyst could expose relatively more oxygen vacancy at lower temperatures, resulting in more catalytic active sites. And the catalytic activity of methane could be greatly enhanced. This was consistent with the result of the catalytic activity evaluation for methane (part 3.1). Combined with XPS and H2-TPR characterization, it could be further demonstrated that oxygen vacancy was the main factor enhancing the methane-catalyzed reaction of CM-2.5DES in this work. 3.9 Composite catalysts combustion characteristics analysis Fig. 12 showed the combustion characteristics curves of CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples measured at the heating rates of 5∼x223C25 °C•min−1. Table S1 showed the combustion characteristics of CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples measured at different heating rates from 5 to 25 °C•min−1. Combined with the graphical data analysis: the combustion of CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples were mainly divided into the following three stages. As for CM-2.5DES samples, Stage 1: 50∼x223C200 °C, the temperature value of the maximum reaction rate in this stage decreased and then increased with the increase of the heating rate; Stage 2: 200∼x223C520 °C, the temperature value of the maximum reaction rate in this stage decreased gradually with the increase of the heating rate. At this stage, the CM-2.5DES sample took a leading role in the combustion process. The combustion of MnCO3 which was the main phase of CM-2.5DES sample occurred in the temperature range of 200∼x223C500 °C, and the reaction was violent in the temperature range of 360∼x223C500 °C;Stage 3: 520∼x223C600 °C, no weight loss occurred in this stage. The final residual mass of the sample indicated that the sample burned more completely with the increasing reaction rate. As for MnCO3 samples, Stage 1: 50∼x223C300 °C, the temperature value of the maximum reaction rate in this stage increased and then decreased with the increase of heating rate; Stage 2: 300∼x223C550 °C, the temperature value of the maximum reaction rate in this stage increased and then decreased with the increase of heating rate. Meanwhile, the MnCO3 sample played a dominant role in the combustion process in this stage. The combustion of MnCO3 which was the main phase of MnCO3 sample occurred in the temperature range of 300∼x223C550 °C, and the reaction was violent in the temperature range of 360∼x223C500 °C; Stage 3: 550∼x223C600 °C, a slight weight loss occurred in this stage. The final residual mass of the sample indicated that the sample burned more completely with the reaction rate increases. Comparison of the combustion characteristics of CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples revealed that the weight loss rate of MnCO3 sample in each stage was greater than CM-2.5DES sample. This indicated that the combustion reaction of the MnCO3 sample was stronger than CM-2.5DES sample at each stage. The second stage played a dominant role in the combustion process of the sample, and the main weight loss stage occurred in this stage. At this stage, the maximum temperature value of CM-2.5DES sample combustion reaction rate was lower than MnCO3 sample. And combustion completion temperature was lower than MnCO3 sample. And the residual mass after combustion of CM-2.5DES sample was also significantly higher than MnCO3 sample. 3.10 Analysis of gaseous products and stability for composite catalysts For the mass spectrometric analysis of gaseous products at combustion of composite catalysts, we used the catalyst activity evaluation fixed-bed reactor ramp-up procedure in Part 2.3 for the experimental analysis. The mass spectral information of escaping gaseous products from the combustion process of CM-2.5DES sample at heating rate of 25 °C•min−1 was chosen because of the relatively fast automatic heating rate in the heating procedure, and analyzed in combination with the sample combustion data in Part 3.9. Fig. 13 showed the mass spectra of the combustion for CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples under different atmospheric conditions. And the x-axis was the mass-to-charge ratio (m/z), the y-axis was the temperature. As shown in Fig. 13 , the mass-to-charge ratios (m/z) of gaseous products during the combustion for CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 samples under the same atmospheric conditions were distributed in the range of 10–50. The CM-2.5DES sample was shown in Fig. 13 -a. In the first stage of temperature from 50 to 300 °C, only H2O+ (m/z = 18) peak was appeared, and OH− (m/z = 17) belonged to its ionization products. The H2O escaping from combustion at this stage was mainly adsorbed water in the sample pores and surface. As shown in Fig. 13 -b, the main gaseous ionic products in the second stage at temperatures from 300 to 550 °C were CO2+ (m/z = 44) and O − (m/z = 16). And the production of CO2 was mainly formed by the breakage of chemical bond between carbon and oxygen of MnCO3 in CM-2.5DES sample, while O− was fragment ion generated by ionization, accompanied by the appearance of H2O+ (m/z = 18) peak. The H2O escaping from combustion at this stage was probably mainly crystalline water in the crystal structure of catalyst. From Fig. 13 -(c) and Fig. 13 -(d), it was found that the gaseous products escaping from the combustion process of MnCO3 sample were the same as those escaping from the combustion process of CM-2.5DES sample. We also solved the activation energy of combustion for CM-2.5DES and MnCO3 materials in the combustion stage by CR and ABSW methods. Detailed graphical data were shown in Fig. S1, Table S2 and Table S3. The activation energy E values of the combustion process for CM-2.5DES sample was calculated as 369.0340 kJ•mol−1 and 378.9610 kJ•mol−1 by two calculation methods, the average value was 373.9975 kJ•mol−1. And the activation energy E values of the combustion process of MnCO3 sample was calculated as 255.3869 kJ•mol−1 and 264.5091 kJ•mol−1 for the two calculation methods, the average value was 259.948 kJ•mol−1. The activation energy of CM-2.5DES sample was significantly higher than MnCO3 sample which indicated that the energy required to break the structure of CM-2.5DES sample in the combustion process was higher than MnCO3 sample, which indicated that the stability of CM-2.5DES sample during combustion was higher than that MnCO3 sample. This meant that the CM-2.5DES sample was more stable in the combustion process than the MnCO3 sample. 4 Conclusion In this study, CuMn2O4 induced precursors were prepared by co-precipitation method, and DES was selected as the inducer. A series of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts were successfully induced and synthesized by hydrothermal method. At the same time, we investigated the effect of different DES additions on the catalytic activity of the catalysts for methane. The prepared CM-2.5DES composite catalyst showed the most excellent catalytic methane performance with T50 and T90 at 325 °C and 425 °C, respectively, at DES addition of 1.5 g. Meanwhile, the CM-2.5DES composite catalyst had the highest specific surface area (15.972 m2•g − 1), the largest pore size (3.831 nm), and a rich pore structure. It also had a high percentage of MnCO3 crystalline phase (abundant active material) and good crystallinity. The XRD results show that the main crystalline phases of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts was MnCO3 and contains Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 crystalline phase, which was consistent with the absorption peaks caused by the of Cu-O and Mn-O and the asymmetric stretching vibration of CO3 2- in the FT-IR pattern. Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts were mainly medium acid-base sites, which reduced the amount of CO2 desorption in strong base sites and effectively promoted the desorption of catalytic reaction products. The Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts exposed more high-valent manganese on the surface (formed high concentration of oxygen vacancies) which was beneficial to the catalytic activity of methane, and the composite catalyst exhibited relatively high thermal stability. coredata.dc:description: A series of Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts for low-temperature catalytic combustion of methane were successfully prepared by synthetic induction of CuMn2O4 precursors via hydrothermal method which used deep eutectic solvent (DES) as an inducer. The structure and properties of the catalyst were investigated by XRD, BET, XPS and SEM characterizations to investigate the effect of DES addition on the crystal growth of the catalyst. The results showed that the Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalyst produced a new phase of MnCO3, which changed the number and distribution of acid-base sites on the catalyst surface and effectively promoted the desorption of catalytic reaction products. The catalytic activity test showed that the methane catalytic activity of the Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalyst was significantly enhanced at Mn/C molar ratio of 1:2.5, with T50 and T90 values of 365 °C and 425 °C, respectively. This can be attributed to the high proportional distribution of high-valent manganese in the internal electronic structure of the composite catalyst system, which generated a large number of surface adsorbed oxygen species and thus facilitated the oxidation of methane at lower temperatures. Thermal analysis of composite catalysts revealed relatively high activation energy and thermal stability in the combustion process of composite catalysts. This study will lead to innovative insights into the design of composite catalysts for methane oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of deep eutectic solvent on Cu-Mn-C-O composite catalysts: Surface species, physical and chemical properties in methane combustion
